case_name: Balakrishna Chetty v. State of Madras

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 490 and 491 of 1958 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 490 and 491 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated February 18, 1955, of the Madras High Court in Second Appeals Nos. 2038 and 2039 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated February 18, 1955, of the Madras High Court in Second Appeals Nos. 2038 and 2039 of 1950.

facts.text: Two suits were brought by the appellants for a declaration against the levy of sales tax by the State of Madras and an injunction was also prayed for.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-Two suits were brought by the appellants for a declaration against the levy of sales tax by the State of Madras and an injunction was also prayed for.

facts.text: Both suits were decreed by the Subordinate Judge of Salem.

anchor.surface_text: Both the suits were decreed by the Subordinate Judge of Salem and the decrees were companyfirmed on appeal by the District Judge of Salem.

facts.text: Decrees confirmed on appeal by the District Judge of Salem.

anchor.surface_text: Both the suits were decreed by the Subordinate Judge of Salem and the decrees were companyfirmed on appeal by the District Judge of Salem.

facts.text: Two appeals taken to the High Court by the State of Madras against those decrees.

anchor.surface_text: Two appeals were taken to the High Court by the State of Madras against those decrees and by a judgment dated February 18, 1955, the decrees were set aside by a companymon judgment.

facts.text: Madras High Court by judgment dated February 18, 1955 set aside the decrees by a common judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Two appeals were taken to the High Court by the State of Madras against those decrees and by a judgment dated February 18, 1955, the decrees were set aside by a companymon judgment.

facts.text: Appellants brought these appeals by a certificate of that Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against these decrees the appellants have brought these appeals by a certificate of that Court.

facts.text: Appellants are merchants dealing in cotton yarn.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are merchants dealing in companyton yarn.

facts.text: Appellants obtained a license under s. 5 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act IX of 1939.

anchor.surface_text: They obtained a license under s. 5 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act  Act IX of 1939 , hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: License issued on March 31, 1941, and renewed for following years.

anchor.surface_text: The license was issued on March 31,1941, and was renewed for the following years.

facts.text: License exempted them from assessment to sales tax under s. 3 on sale of cotton yarn and handloom cloth subject to restrictions and conditions.

anchor.surface_text: This license exempted them from assessment to sales tax under s. 3 of the Act on the sale of companyton yarn and on handloom cloth subject to such restrictions and companyditions as may be prescribed including companyditions as to license and license fees.

facts.text: On September 20, 1944, Commercial Tax Authorities made a surprise inspection of the premises of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: On September 20, 1944, the Commercial Tax Authorities made a surprise inspection of the premises of the appellants and discovered that they were maintaining two separate sets of account

facts.text: Inspection discovered appellants maintaining two separate sets of accounts, one for returns to Department, other showed black-market activities.

anchor.surface_text: and discovered that they were maintaining two separate sets of account on the basis of one of which the appellants submitted their returns to the Department. Because the other set of account books showed black-market activities

facts.text: Balakrishna Chetty prosecuted and sentenced to six months imprisonment for offence connected with breach of Cotton Yarn Control Order.

anchor.surface_text: of the firm Balakrishna Chetty was prosecuted and sentenced to six months imprisonment for an offence companynected with the breach of Cot. ton Yarn Control Order.

facts.text: Deputy Commercial Tax Officer made assessments for 1943-44 (Rs. 37,039) and 1944-45 (Rs. 3,140).

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of those proceedings the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer made assessments for the years. 1943- 44 and 1944-45, the tax for the former was Rs. 37,039 and for the latter Rs. 3,140.

facts.text: Appellants appealed against assessments unsuccessfully, revisions also failed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants unsuccessfully appealed against these assessments and their revisions also failed.

facts.text: On August 24, 1945, appellants brought suit for declaration and injunction regarding first assessment.

anchor.surface_text: On August 24, 1945, the appellants brought a suit for a declaration and injunction in regard to the first assessment alleging that the assessment was against the Act.

facts.text: On September 2, 1946, similar suit brought regarding second assessment.

anchor.surface_text: On September 2, 1946, a similar suit was brought in regard to the second assessment.

facts.text: High Court held that observance of conditions of license necessary for exemption under s.5; appellants contravened conditions, liable to pay tax.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has held that on a true interpretation of the provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder, the observance of companyditions of the license was necessary for the availability of exemption under s. 5 that as the appellants had companytravened those companyditions

facts.text: Appellants contended that holding license sufficient for exemption even if infractions.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention raised on behalf of the appellants was that as long as they held the licence it was immaterial if they were guilty of any infraction of the law and that they were number liable to any assessment of sales-tax

facts.text: Court held appellants contravened provisions of the Act and rules, not entitled to exemption.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants have been found to have companytravened the provisions of the Act as well as the rules and therefore it cannot be said that they have observed the companyditions upon which the exemption under the licence is available.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 29, 1960 by KAPUR, J.

issues.text: What is the correct interpretation of the words 'subject to' in Section 5 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939?

anchor.surface_text: The companytroversy between the parties centres round the interpretation of the words subject to in s. 5 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the observance of conditions of the license is necessary for the availability of exemption under Section 5 despite holding the license?

anchor.surface_text: the observance of companyditions of the license was necessary for the availability of exemption under s. 5 that as the appellants had companytravened those companyditions

issues.text: Whether holding a license under Section 5 is sufficient to claim exemption even in spite of breaches of its terms and conditions?

anchor.surface_text: The companytention raised on behalf of the appellants was that as long as they held the licence it was immaterial if they were guilty of any infraction of the law and that they were number liable to any assessment of sales-tax under the provisions of the Act and the only penalty they incurred was to have their licence cancelled and or be liable to the penalty which under the criminal law they had already suffered. The companytention companyes to this that in spite of the breaches of the terms and companyditions of the licence, having a licence was sufficient for the purpose of exemption under the Act.

issues.text: Whether the phrase 'subject to' in Section 5 means 'conditional upon' observance of prescribed restrictions and conditions or merely 'liable to' the rules and provisions of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: But it was companytended that the words subject to do number mean companyditional upon but liable to the rules and the provisions of the Act. So -construed s. 5 will become number only inelegant but wholly meaningless. On a proper interpretation of the section it only means that the exemption under the licence is companyditional upon the observance of the companyditions prescribed and upon the restrictions which are imposed by and under the Act whether in the rules or in the licence itself

arguments.claim: As long as the appellants held the licence it was immaterial if they were guilty of any infraction of the law and they were not liable to any assessment of sales-tax; the only penalty was licence cancellation or criminal penalty despite breaches.

anchor.surface_text: The contention raised on behalf of the appellants was that as long as they held the licence it was immaterial if they were guilty of any infraction of the law and that they were not liable to any assessment of sales-tax under the provisions of the Act and the only penalty they incurred was to have their licence cancelled and or be liable to the penalty which under the criminal law they had already suffered. The contention comes to this that in spite of the breaches of the terms and conditions of the licence, having a licence was sufficient for the purpose of exemption under the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: in spite of the breaches of the terms and companyditions of the licence, having a licence was sufficient for the purpose of exemption under the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: This contention, in our opinion, is wholly untenable. Section 3 is the charging section and s. 5 gives exemption from taxation but that section clearly makes the holding of a licence subject to restrictions and conditions prescribed.

arguments.claim: The words 'subject to' do not mean conditional upon but liable to the rules and the provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: But it was contended that the words subject to do not mean conditional upon but liable to the rules and the provisions of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Act and the rules. But it was companytended that the words subject to do number mean companyditional upon but liable to the rules and the provisions

arguments.court_reasoning: So-construed s. 5 will become not only inelegant but wholly meaningless.

arguments.claim: On a true interpretation of the provisions of the Act and the rules, the observance of conditions of the license was necessary for the availability of exemption under s. 5; appellants contravened those conditions and were liable to pay tax notwithstanding the license.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has held that on a true interpretation of the provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder, the observance of conditions of the license was necessary for the availability of exemption under s. 5 that as the appellants had contravened those conditions

court_response_anchor.surface_text: may be prescribed. Under B. 13 an important companydition imposed under the Act is the keeping by the dealer and every person licensed of true and co

arguments.court_reasoning: The Supreme Court agrees with this interpretation and applies it to affirm the High Court's decision.

arguments.claim: The exemption under s. 5 is subject to such restrictions and conditions as may be prescribed, including conditions as to licenses and license fees; 'subject to' means conditional upon observance of conditions prescribed under the Act, rules, and license itself.

anchor.surface_text: This contention, in our opinion, is wholly untenable. Section 3 is the charging section and s. 5 gives exemption from taxation but that section clearly makes the holding of a licence subject to restrictions and conditions prescribed under the provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder because the opening words of that section are subject to such restrictions and conditions as may be prescribed.

arguments.claim: Under s.13, r.5, Form III, and r.8, licensees must keep true and correct accounts and comply with Act and rules to avail exemption; the license is issued subject to these, and breach results in loss of exemption.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 13 an important condition imposed under the Act is the keeping by the dealer and every person licensed of true and correct accounts showing the value of the goods sold and paid by him. Next there is r. 5 of the General Sales Tax Rules which provided that if any person desired to avail himself of the exemption provided in s. 5, he had to submit an application in Form I for a licence and the Form of the licence shows that the licence was subject to the provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder which required the licensee to submit returns as required and also to keep true accounts under s.

arguments.claim: The appellants contravened provisions of the Act (s.13 accounts) and rules by maintaining false accounts and black-market activities, so they did not observe conditions for exemption under the licence.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants have been found to have contravened the provisions of the Act as well as the rules and therefore it cannot be said that they have observed the conditions upon which the exemption under the licence is available. In that view of the matter, it was rightly held that they were not exempt from assessment under the Act.

holdings.text: This contention, in our opinion, is wholly untenable. Section 3 is the charging section and s. 5 gives exemption from taxation but that section clearly makes the holding of a licence subject to restrictions and conditions prescribed under the provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder because the opening words of that section are subject to such restrictions and conditions as may be prescribed.

anchor.surface_text: This contention, in our opinion, is wholly untenable. Section 3 is the charging section and s. 5 gives exemption from taxation but that section clearly makes the holding of a licence subject to restrictions and conditions prescribed under the provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder because the opening words of that section are subject to such restrictions and conditions as may be prescribed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects appellant's claim that mere possession of license suffices despite breaches; s.3 imposes tax, s.5 exempts only subject to prescribed conditions.

holdings.text: Under s. 13 an important condition imposed under the Act is the keeping by the dealer and every person licensed of true and correct accounts showing the value of the goods sold and paid by him. Next there is r. 5 of the General Sales Tax Rules which provided that if any person desired to avail himself of the exemption provided in s. 5, he had to submit an application in Form I for a licence and the Form of the licence shows that the licence was subject to the provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder which required the licensee to submit returns as required and also to keep true accounts under s.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 13 an important condition imposed under the Act is the keeping by the dealer and every person licensed of true and correct accounts showing the value of the goods sold and paid by him. Next there is r. 5 of the General Sales Tax Rules which provided that if any person desired to avail himself of the exemption provided in s. 5, he had to submit an application in Form I for a licence and the Form of the licence shows that the licence was subject to the provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder which required the licensee to submit returns as required and also to keep true accounts under s.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Identifies specific conditions under s.13, r.5, Form III as requirements for exemption; license issued subject to Act and rules.

holdings.text: But it was contended that the words subject to do not mean conditional upon but liable to the rules and the provisions of the Act. So -construed s. 5 will become not only inelegant but wholly meaningless.

anchor.surface_text: But it was contended that the words subject to do not mean conditional upon but liable to the rules and the provisions of the Act. So -construed s. 5 will become not only inelegant but wholly meaningless.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative interpretation renders s.5 meaningless; rejects 'liable to' in favor of 'conditional upon'.

holdings.text: On a proper interpretation of the section it only means that the exemption under the licence is conditional upon the observance of the conditions prescribed and upon the restrictions which are imposed by and under the Act whether in the rules or in the licence itself that is, a licensee is exempt from assessment as long as he complies to the conditions of the licence and not that he is entitled to exemption whether the conditions upon which the licence is given are fulfilled or not.

anchor.surface_text: On a proper interpretation of the section it only means that the exemption under the licence is conditional upon the observance of the conditions prescribed and upon the restrictions which are imposed by and under the Act whether in the rules or in the licence itself that is, a licensee is exempt from assessment as long as he complies to the conditions of the licence and not that he is entitled to exemption whether the conditions upon which the licence is given are fulfilled or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proper textual and purposive reading of s.5 makes exemption conditional on compliance with conditions in Act, rules, and license.

holdings.text: The appellants have been found to have contravened the provisions of the Act as well as the rules and therefore it cannot be said that they have observed the conditions upon which the exemption under the licence is available. In that view of the matter, it was rightly held that they were not exempt from assessment under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants have been found to have contravened the provisions of the Act as well as the rules and therefore it cannot be said that they have observed the conditions upon which the exemption under the licence is available. In that view of the matter, it was rightly held that they were not exempt from assessment under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants maintained false accounts and engaged in black-market, breaching s.13 and rules; thus lost exemption despite license.

anchor.surface_text: This contention, in our opinion, is wholly untenable. Section 3 is the charging section and s. 5 gives exemption from taxation but that section clearly makes the holding of a licence subject to restrictions and conditions prescribed under the provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder because the opening words of that section are subject to such restrictions and conditions as may be prescribed.

The appellants have been found to have contravened the provisions of the Act as well as the rules and therefore it cannot be said that they have observed the conditions upon which the exemption under the licence is available. In that view of the matter, it was rightly held that they were not exempt from assessment under the Act.

Next there is r. 5 of the General Sales Tax Rules which provided that if any person desired to avail himself of the exemption provided in s. 5, he had to submit an application in Form I for a licence and the Form of the licence shows that the licence was subject to the provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder which required the licensee to submit returns as required and also to keep true accounts under s.

The appellants have been found to have contravened the provisions of the Act as well as the rules and therefore it cannot be said that they have observed the conditions upon which the exemption under the licence is available.
